description: The Microsoft Word 2016 show helps a viewer to have a fundamental understanding of the Word 2016 environment and the ability to complete tasks independently.  The show demonstrates the correct application of the principal features of Word 2016.  Viewing all the episodes should help viewers to create and edit basic documents  for a variety of purposes and situations.  This should help someone who might be a student, clerical worker, IT support staff as well as someone seeking the Microsoft Office Specialist Certification.
name: Word 2016 - Level 1
subtitle: Word Processing Application

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Mike look at getting started using Microsoft Office Word 2016. They look at different ways to launch Word, like pinning to the taskbar and desktop shortcuts. They also look at launching Word in safe mode if Word won't launch normally. They explore some of the options in Word, like the quick access toolbar.

00:25:19.770 --> 00:25:21.610
But anytime you have
those graphic elements,

490
00:25:21.610 --> 00:25:25.460
anytime you have all these other things
that normally are also associated with

491
00:25:25.460 --> 00:25:28.365
a PDF, is probably not going
to work as well for you.

492
00:25:28.365 --> 00:25:31.567
You'll probably end up also
seeing little character marks

493
00:25:31.567 --> 00:25:35.163
every once in a while like a square
that's faded out or something.

494
00:25:35.163 --> 00:25:37.580
In other words, it was some mark
it just couldn't interpret.

495
00:25:37.580 --> 00:25:42.310
But overall though, this is what you can
have if everything is actually set up.

496
00:25:42.310 --> 00:25:45.476
But if it's not, you'll see that it also
does what we call a document reflowing,

497
00:25:45.476 --> 00:25:47.990
and that's how Word does this.

498
00:25:47.990 --> 00:25:51.690
Word takes a PDF document, even though
that's supposed to be locked in place, and

499
00:25:51.690 --> 00:25:54.670
it'll reflow it to keep
its reading compatibility.

500
00:25:54.670 --> 00:25:57.678
So it wants to make sure it actually
is readable during the whole time.

501
00:25:57.678 --> 00:26:02.110
And that reflow can work for you,
it can also work against you.

502
00:26:02.110 --> 00:26:04.635
When you open it up, so
you do have to be careful.

503
00:26:04.635 --> 00:26:08.515
Don't assume that just because
the first 10 pages of your 200 page

504
00:26:08.515 --> 00:26:11.345
thing that you've brought
in is actually fine.

505
00:26:11.345 --> 00:26:13.205
You do need to inspect every page.

506
00:26:13.205 --> 00:26:17.525
If not, you'll find yourself with
surprises on 10 to 15, if not even more,

507
00:26:17.525 --> 00:26:19.885
of those pages that you're not expecting.

508
00:26:19.885 --> 00:26:24.045
And that's when it becomes disappointing,
when you take the time to do all that.

509
00:26:24.045 --> 00:26:26.233
But as long as a document is mainly text,
and

510
00:26:26.233 --> 00:26:30.613
you're willing to deal with the reflow, it
doesn't have to look exactly like the PDF,

511
00:26:30.613 --> 00:26:31.931
then you can also do this.

512
00:26:31.931 --> 00:26:34.932
And bring it in, and at this point,
you can save it as a Word document and

513
00:26:34.932 --> 00:26:36.910
be able to actually work
with it in editing it.

514
00:26:36.910 --> 00:26:40.520
And so large files that you might have
said, oh yeah, that was saved as a PDF.

515
00:26:40.520 --> 00:26:44.390
But let's say that we wanted to
rerelease it under my own publication.

516
00:26:44.390 --> 00:26:46.014
I couldn't do that with Ardour.

517
00:26:46.014 --> 00:26:49.145
But let's say that we did have old
manuscripts that we wanted to do that

518
00:26:49.145 --> 00:26:51.530
with, but they were all saved as PDFs.

519
00:26:51.530 --> 00:26:52.320
It can do it.

520
00:26:52.320 --> 00:26:56.214
So it's actually a way that you can
now bring those old copies back and

521
00:26:56.214 --> 00:27:00.130
be able to actually edit,
modernize the text, get ready to go.

522
00:27:00.130 --> 00:27:02.330
>> And I want to make sure I
clarify what I said there.

523
00:27:02.330 --> 00:27:06.440
I noticed that the Adobe PDF
says proprietary.

524
00:27:06.440 --> 00:27:08.610
It's not really that they released that.

525
00:27:08.610 --> 00:27:12.030
I know that they did finally pass
that over to an ISO committee.

526
00:27:12.030 --> 00:27:16.541
There are still some components within it
that are proprietary which is, I think,

527
00:27:16.541 --> 00:27:20.674
where some of the hang-up comes in where
we try to open something like that.

528
00:27:20.674 --> 00:27:25.399
But it's no longer proprietary,
at least the PDF format.

529
00:27:25.399 --> 00:27:26.860
Fantastic stuff there, Ronnie.

530
00:27:26.860 --> 00:27:29.330
I feel like we're really
making some headway.

531
00:27:29.330 --> 00:27:32.140
We've learned about that interface,
we're able to navigate around,

532
00:27:32.140 --> 00:27:34.510
now we're starting to see how
we can create these documents.

533
00:27:34.510 --> 00:27:38.020
You either create it from scratch,
if I know where I want to go and

534
00:27:38.020 --> 00:27:41.855
what I want to do, or if I need a head
start or if I need a starting point,

535
00:27:41.855 --> 00:27:45.105
Microsoft has plenty of templates
that I can go out online,

536
00:27:45.105 --> 00:27:48.752
and I can search, and I can maybe
use that as a jumping-off point.

537
00:27:48.752 --> 00:27:51.364
I might find one that fits
my needs exactly, and

538
00:27:51.364 --> 00:27:54.495
all I have to do is go in there and
click on a couple things,

539
00:27:54.495 --> 00:27:57.980
replace their filler text with my text and
save it, I'm done.

540
00:27:57.980 --> 00:28:00.772
Or I might use it as a starting point and
then go ahead and

541
00:28:00.772 --> 00:28:02.840
tweak it a little bit and make it my own.

542
00:28:02.840 --> 00:28:04.465
So fantastic stuff.

543
00:28:04.465 --> 00:28:08.310
Heck, if I do something really cool,
I can load it back up to the community and

544
00:28:08.310 --> 00:28:11.650
let other people take a look
at my template that I created,

545
00:28:11.650 --> 00:28:14.200
maybe somebody else will find it useful.

546
00:28:14.200 --> 00:28:17.130
We saw how Word can open
up different formats.

547
00:28:17.130 --> 00:28:21.370
We have older formats from
previous versions of Word as well

548
00:28:21.370 --> 00:28:23.325
as formats from other applications,

549
00:28:23.325 --> 00:28:29.230
non-native Word formats is able
to at least open them up usually.

550
00:28:29.230 --> 00:28:32.356
Maybe not make it perfect,
but a good starting point.

551
00:28:32.356 --> 00:28:33.430
So great information there, Ronnie.

552
00:28:33.430 --> 00:28:37.550
Any words for our viewers
before we call this one an end?

553
00:28:37.550 --> 00:28:42.160
>> Remember, that Word is kind of now,
as you see, a fairly universal type

554
00:28:42.160 --> 00:28:46.840
of program that you can use to help
you to begin creating your dockets.

555
00:28:46.840 --> 00:28:48.300
So don't be afraid to try it.

556
00:28:48.300 --> 00:28:49.630
It's not going to break Word,

557
00:28:49.630 --> 00:28:52.480
if you happen to bring the document
that says it can't do it.

558
00:28:52.480 --> 00:28:54.250
It'll just tell you it can't do it.

559
00:28:54.250 --> 00:28:56.960
So if you're really just starting out,
try it.

560
00:28:56.960 --> 00:28:59.110
Why not, see what ends up happening.

561
00:28:59.110 --> 00:29:03.080
It may actually get you 90% of
the way you want to get started, and

562
00:29:03.080 --> 00:29:06.760
then from that point, you can use
the skills that you've already learned

563
00:29:06.760 --> 00:29:10.410
to continue on and to modify, and
then to make what you actually need to.

564
00:29:10.410 --> 00:29:13.930
But this is a great place for us to begin,
is understanding that we have so

565
00:29:13.930 --> 00:29:16.160
much flexibility right
there inside of Word.

566
00:29:16.160 --> 00:29:19.295
That it really is one of most
helpful utilities that we can use,

567
00:29:19.295 --> 00:29:20.725
if we have to deal with text.

568
00:29:20.725 --> 00:29:23.640
>> Fantastic, all right, Ronnie,
thanks for all that information.

569
00:29:23.640 --> 00:29:25.219
Hope everybody enjoyed watching.

570
00:29:25.219 --> 00:29:27.600
Signing off for ITProTV,
I'm Mike Roderick.

571
00:29:27.600 --> 00:29:28.140
>> And I'm Ronnie Wong.

572
00:29:28.140 --> 00:29:29.538
>> And we'll see you next time.

573
00:29:29.538 --> 00:29:35.770
[SOUND]

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Mike look at ways to navigate through a document. They start with different ways to select text. Then they demonstrate how to use the find and replace options.
episodes.title: Navigate a Document
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.803 --> 00:00:15.931
Hello, and welcome to another
exciting episode at ITProTV.

3
00:00:15.931 --> 00:00:18.130
I'm your host, Mike Rodrick.

4
00:00:18.130 --> 00:00:21.130
And today we're gonna be
looking at Word 2016.

5
00:00:21.130 --> 00:00:24.150
And specifically in this episode
we're gonna learn how to

6
00:00:24.150 --> 00:00:27.390
navigate around documents,
use our different selection tools,

7
00:00:27.390 --> 00:00:30.020
especially in these larger documents.

8
00:00:30.020 --> 00:00:33.420
And who better to help us with
that than Mr. Ronnie Wong?

9
00:00:33.420 --> 00:00:38.010
Now, Ronnie I know that the other day we
started to get comfortable with Word and

10
00:00:38.010 --> 00:00:41.550
we were able to navigate around,
but now I've got this really

11
00:00:41.550 --> 00:00:45.760
long document that somebody's giving me,
and I've gotta go in and edit it and

12
00:00:45.760 --> 00:00:48.910
make some changes to it,
find certain things in there.

13
00:00:48.910 --> 00:00:52.590
So I'm hoping that maybe some of those
techniques that we looked at before

14
00:00:52.590 --> 00:00:53.640
could apply to this?

15
00:00:53.640 --> 00:00:54.910
>> They really can.

16
00:00:54.910 --> 00:00:57.830
Inside of Word, remember that
the majority of the time when

17
00:00:57.830 --> 00:01:01.450
you're working at is not just gonna be
opening up a document and then writing.

18
00:01:01.450 --> 00:01:04.460
Don't get me wrong, if your job's
a writer, that maybe all you want to do.

19
00:01:04.460 --> 00:01:06.960
But even as a writer, a lot of
times you're opening up things like

20
00:01:06.960 --> 00:01:10.770
chapters that you're going back through
and re-editing and rewriting, and

21
00:01:10.770 --> 00:01:12.250
doing a lot of things like that.

22
00:01:12.250 --> 00:01:15.420
Or let's say that you are actually that
assistant that's given this that says,

23
00:01:15.420 --> 00:01:17.850
look, you need to go
through that document and

24
00:01:17.850 --> 00:01:22.020
be able to find these instances where I
actually did something like this, and

25
00:01:22.020 --> 00:01:24.100
go through them, and then you look
down and you're like, wait a minute,

26
00:01:24.100 --> 00:01:27.285
that's a pretty long document,
like what Mike was saying.

27
00:01:27.285 --> 00:01:30.090
Then now you're actually having to go,
okay, if I read through this,

28
00:01:30.090 --> 00:01:32.980
it's gonna take me half an hour, and
then I'm not finding everything.

29
00:01:32.980 --> 00:01:35.690
>> Yeah, if it's a 200 page document,
I'm looking for a word.

30
00:01:35.690 --> 00:01:37.340
That's like finding
a needle in a haystack.

31
00:01:37.340 --> 00:01:39.150
There's gotta be an easier way to do it.

32
00:01:39.150 --> 00:01:40.030
>> There really are.

33
00:01:40.030 --> 00:01:44.250
And the good thing is, Word has a lot of
tools that are available that you and

34
00:01:44.250 --> 00:01:47.360
I should at least feel
somewhat comfortable with.

35
00:01:47.360 --> 00:01:49.828
All of the ways that we
can actually go ahead and

36
00:01:49.828 --> 00:01:53.830
use those built-in tools to help us
to find exactly what we need to.

37
00:01:53.830 --> 00:01:57.076
Now, remember, the manual way is pretty
much the way that you probably learned

38
00:01:57.076 --> 00:02:00.241
from the very beginning as you worked
with single-page documents, right?

39
00:02:00.241 --> 00:02:03.591
Having that eagle eye view where you
could read just every line, and go, okay,

40
00:02:03.591 --> 00:02:07.241
I've proofed that, everything looks good,
I like the way that it's formatted out,

41
00:02:07.241 --> 00:02:08.503
and that's perfectly fine.

42
00:02:08.503 --> 00:02:11.999
But now when you start working with
documents that are, let's say, five pages,

43
00:02:11.999 --> 00:02:15.393
ten pages long, and then you start reading
it and you start going through like,

44
00:02:15.393 --> 00:02:16.931
that doesn't make logical sense.

45
00:02:16.931 --> 00:02:20.854
And now you have to go back and navigate
back through it, and you keep scrolling,

46
00:02:20.854 --> 00:02:23.168
and that scroll wheel
works perfectly fine.

47
00:02:23.168 --> 00:02:26.860
All of us use the scroll wheel to go back
and forth between a couple of pages.

48
00:02:26.860 --> 00:02:31.650
But now when we start talking about 10 or
20 pages, or a 200 page document that Mike

49
00:02:31.650 --> 00:02:35.530
is referring to, now, it becomes much more
difficult, and most of us are gonna need

50
00:02:35.530 --> 00:02:40.160
assistance in doing that, and Word really
does help us to be able to do that.

51
00:02:40.160 --> 00:02:43.910
So, let's go ahead and take a look, then,
at a document that I went ahead and

52
00:02:43.910 --> 00:02:45.717
pulled up, a fairly long document.

53
00:02:45.717 --> 00:02:50.160
So, this is a document that I've pulled in
from public domain on the Internet, and

54
00:02:50.160 --> 00:02:52.071
it's a relatively long document.

55
00:02:52.071 --> 00:02:55.549
So when you start looking at something
like this and you're told, hey,

56
00:02:55.549 --> 00:02:59.426
you need to go through here, and there are
instances that what we need to do is find

57
00:02:59.426 --> 00:03:03.160
a place where the word A appeared and
we need to replace it with an N.

58
00:03:03.160 --> 00:03:07.399
In other words an AN instead because well,
if Ronnie had written the document and

59
00:03:07.399 --> 00:03:11.500
let's say that he just doesn't know that
you're supposed to use the N instead,

60
00:03:11.500 --> 00:03:14.310
that takes a long time when
you're replacing a single letter.

61
00:03:14.310 --> 00:03:16.078
And when you do that, it can be done, but

62
00:03:16.078 --> 00:03:19.110
you do have to use the tools that
are actually in there to help you out.

63
00:03:19.110 --> 00:03:22.868
If not, it means you're manually gonna
go through it, and you're just gonna go,

64
00:03:22.868 --> 00:03:25.550
okay, every time I see an A by itself,
I need to mark that and

65
00:03:25.550 --> 00:03:28.560
then make sure I replace it with N,
but that slows you down.

66
00:03:28.560 --> 00:03:30.560
But there are features and
tools that are in there.

67
00:03:30.560 --> 00:03:32.020
But one of the things we wanna point out,

68
00:03:32.020 --> 00:03:35.810
though, is just when you start
taking look at this document,

69
00:03:35.810 --> 00:03:39.160
right, let's make sure we understand
the scope of it to take a look here.

70
00:03:39.160 --> 00:03:43.036
So on my screen,
this is a 26-page document, and

71
00:03:43.036 --> 00:03:47.930
I'm gonna try and zoom in here if
I can to try and show you that.

72
00:03:47.930 --> 00:03:50.880
Right down here in
the lower left-hand corner

73
00:03:50.880 --> 00:03:53.900
you can see where says page 1 of 26.

74
00:03:53.900 --> 00:03:55.475
Now the text is a little bit small.

75
00:03:55.475 --> 00:03:57.520
I'm zoomed in here,
doesn't look that great, but

76
00:03:57.520 --> 00:04:00.060
I'm gonna actually zoom
back out here in a moment.

77
00:04:00.060 --> 00:04:01.680
And we want to make
this thing look better.

78
00:04:01.680 --> 00:04:02.960
But right at the beginning,

79
00:04:02.960 --> 00:04:05.790
I just want to show you the idea
of working with this long docket.

80
00:04:05.790 --> 00:04:10.250
26 pages, if I had to go through and
find stuff, it would be very difficult.

81
00:04:10.250 --> 00:04:11.070
>> Yeah, absolutely.

82
00:04:11.070 --> 00:04:14.950
I can't imagine going through trying to
find every instance of a particular word,

83
00:04:14.950 --> 00:04:16.640
doing it manually.

84
00:04:16.640 --> 00:04:19.640
One, I'm probably gonna
get tired of doing that.

85
00:04:19.640 --> 00:04:21.210
Two, I'm probably gonna miss one or
two, right.

86
00:04:21.210 --> 00:04:23.260
And that's not gonna be a good thing,

87
00:04:23.260 --> 00:04:26.220
cuz I think I'm done,
I turn it in and they're like, nope,

88
00:04:26.220 --> 00:04:29.740
you didn't catch all of the occurrences
of that word and now I'm in trouble.

89
00:04:29.740 --> 00:04:31.530
>> Yeah,
there's a lot of this that goes on.

90
00:04:31.530 --> 00:04:35.690
So what are some of the tools that you and
I can use just to find something?

91
00:04:35.690 --> 00:04:38.890
Well, one of the easiest tools that we
have available, if we're not gonna try and

92
00:04:38.890 --> 00:04:42.440
depend on our eye sight in going
through a 26 page document, of course,

93
00:04:42.440 --> 00:04:46.690
is what we call the find tool
that's actually inside of Word.

94
00:04:46.690 --> 00:04:48.089
So, if I take a look then,

95
00:04:48.089 --> 00:04:52.600
across the top here of Word, I'm gonna
go ahead and click on the Home tab.

96
00:04:52.600 --> 00:04:57.530
And then, over here on the right-hand
side where there's the editing group,

97
00:04:57.530 --> 00:04:59.830
notice that we have a collection
of those three tools again.

98
00:04:59.830 --> 00:05:04.370
And I'm gonna kinda zoom in just briefly
so that you can see it says Find,

99
00:05:04.370 --> 00:05:06.270
Replace, and Select.

100
00:05:06.270 --> 00:05:09.240
And those are the tools
that we are talking about.

101
00:05:09.240 --> 00:05:12.420
Now, along with this,
to help you to get more confident and

102
00:05:12.420 --> 00:05:13.610
comfortable with working with this,

103
00:05:13.610 --> 00:05:18.590
of course, are those tools also end up
having a shortcut associated with them.

104
00:05:18.590 --> 00:05:20.990
And as you hover over each of those tools,

105
00:05:20.990 --> 00:05:23.852
you'll see that it also
provides you that shortcut.

106
00:05:23.852 --> 00:05:26.310
So for example, for the find tool,

107
00:05:26.310 --> 00:05:30.830
which has a little icon of
a magnifying glass, it say Ctrl+F.

108
00:05:30.830 --> 00:05:37.010
If I were just looking for a particular
word, I can do a Ctrl+F on my keyboard,

109
00:05:37.010 --> 00:05:41.130
and that brings me to this
navigation pane over here.

110
00:05:41.130 --> 00:05:43.850
And then I can type in
the word that I'm looking for.

111
00:05:43.850 --> 00:05:47.850
So if I wanted to I could type in, and
on this particular document I need to look

112
00:05:47.850 --> 00:05:51.680
for the word, and I'm not gonna be able
to spell it right, is principalities.

113
00:05:53.410 --> 00:05:56.050
And you're probably wondering like,
what the heck did he pull up?

114
00:05:56.050 --> 00:05:57.230
I pulled up the prints.

115
00:05:57.230 --> 00:06:00.070
Because there's actually a document
that was either in public domain, and

116
00:06:00.070 --> 00:06:01.410
I was looking for words.

117
00:06:01.410 --> 00:06:04.140
And now you can see where it
actually goes through and

118
00:06:04.140 --> 00:06:09.620
finds every single one of
the words in this results here,

119
00:06:09.620 --> 00:06:13.910
and shows me all the places where
the word principalities appears.

120
00:06:13.910 --> 00:06:15.790
And you might be saying, well,
how the heck did you know it was in there?

121
00:06:15.790 --> 00:06:16.901
Cuz I actually read through the document.

122
00:06:16.901 --> 00:06:18.511
And I said,
here's a word that appears over and

123
00:06:18.511 --> 00:06:20.240
over again throughout this document.

124
00:06:20.240 --> 00:06:24.330
But if I wanted to,
I could find that and see that.

125
00:06:24.330 --> 00:06:27.430
So a lot of times when you're actually
trying to work with something like this

126
00:06:27.430 --> 00:06:29.490
and they tell you, you need to
find every instance of this and

127
00:06:29.490 --> 00:06:33.055
replace it with a word, and the reason
why I'm not wanting to replace that with

128
00:06:33.055 --> 00:06:35.770
a word is, Mike, do you know what
the term principality means?

129
00:06:35.770 --> 00:06:36.925
>> I don't.
>> I did not know.

130
00:06:36.925 --> 00:06:41.007
Of all things, I was like, of course
I know what it means it means, no,

131
00:06:41.007 --> 00:06:43.905
apparently I don't know
what it actually means.

132
00:06:43.905 --> 00:06:46.070
>> [LAUGH] Can you use
that in a sentence please?

133
00:06:46.070 --> 00:06:47.496
>> Yeah, can I use that in a sentence?

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Mike demonstrate how to apply formatting to a document. They use Page Setup to adjust the margins of a document. They apply styles to elements within a document, and themes that apply to the entire document. They create and add headers and footers to a document, as well as page numbers. They also show how to add a watermark to a document.

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Mike explore the different document views available in Word, including reading, print, web, outline and draft. Then they show how to customize the quick access toolbar as well as customizing the ribbons. They also show how to view different parts of a document at the same time using split view. They finish the show with a look at macros and demonstrate recording a simple macro.

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Mike demonstrate printing a document. They look at the print preview feature, and the different options available when printing. They show how to print an entire document or just part of a document. They also show how to scale a document to print on different size paper. Then they demonstrate how to password protect and share a document.

episodes.description: In this episode Ronnie and Wes demonstrate how to control the look of your Word documents. They look at preventing widowed and orphaned lines from adding themselves to extra pages. They talk about how to separate blocks of text into sections as well as using columns to adjust the appearance of the text. They will explore how to insert page breaks into the document to make sure that paragraphs are kept in order and not separated into different pages of the Word document.
